node.title: World War II bomb explodes near Munich's main train station, injuring four
node.alt: Firefighters, police officers and railway employees are seen at a railway site
node.description: A World War II bomb explodes on a construction site near a busy train station in central Munich, injuring four people.
node.content:
["Four people were injured when what is believed to be an old aircraft bomb exploded at a bridge near Munich's busy main train station on Wednesday.", "The Munich fire brigade said one person\u00a0was seriously injured, after local police first reported the incident on Twitter.", "The explosion happened as the site was being drilled to build a tunnel, police said, adding the area had been cordoned off.", "\"There is no danger outside this area,\" police said.", "Explosives experts were summoned to the site to examine the remains of the bomb, the fire brigade said.", "Due to the blast, rail travel to and from the main train station was suspended, according to rail operator Deutsche Bahn.", "It was not clear when rail traffic would resume.", "", "
World War II bombs are reguarly found in Germany.(AP: Sven Hoppe/dpa)
", "More than 2,000 tonnes of live bombs and munitions are discovered each year in Germany, more than 70 years after the end of World War II.", "The Bombs are regularly discovered during construction work in Germany and are usually defused by experts or destroyed in controlled explosions.", "British and American warplanes pummelled the country with 1.5 million tonnes of bombs that killed 600,000 people.", "Officials estimate that 15 per cent\u00a0of the bombs failed to explode, some of which are buried six metres deep in the ground.", "There have been cases of deadly blasts in the past.", "Three police explosives experts in Goettingen were killed in 2010 while preparing to defuse a 1,000-pound bomb, and in 2014 a construction worker in Euskirchen was killed when his power shovel struck a buried 4,000-pound bomb.", "In 1994, three Berlin construction workers were killed in a similar accident.", "In 2012, a fireball lit up the sky in Munich, causing millions of euros of damage to 17 buildings, when authorities had to detonate a deteriorated 500-pound bomb.", "In 2015, a 1,000-pound bomb ripped a three-metre-deep hole in a motorway near Offenbach in central Germany.\u00a0", "Reuters"]
